author: Samuel Rubenfeld
title: Corruption Currents: Man Jailed for 660 Years Wants His Gold Bars Back - Risk & Compliance Journal. - WSJ
text:
0 COMMENTS A worker stacks 12.5-kilogram gold bullion bars at the Valcambi SA precious metal refinery in Lugano, Switzerland, on April 24, 2018. Photo: Bloomberg News
A daily roundup of corruption news from across the Web. We also provide a daily roundup of important risk & compliance stories via our daily newsletter, The Morning Risk Report, which readers can sign up for here . Follow us on Twitter at @WSJRisk.
Bribery:
Spain’s ruling party benefited from a bribery scheme , a court ruled. More than two dozen people were convicted . A former minister was arrested ; the story didn’t contain a response. (Guardian, EP, BBC, AP, Xinhua)
Israel’s attorney general told the welfare minister he’s about to be indicted. (ToI)
Local cases: A Long Island town official was acquitted of bribery charges; the jury reached a partial verdict. A Detroit airport manager allegedly took bribes and ate the evidence ; his lawyer didn’t respond to requests for comment. Another Detroit area official faces a trial. Two Burmese military officers were transferred after being caught taking bribes. Thai police officers face disciplinary action for allegedly trying to bribe their superiors. (LIH, Reuters, ABC, DN, DN, MD, Irawaddy, BP)
Money Laundering:
A man serving 660 years in prison for laundering money on behalf of a Colombian drug cartel wants his gold bars back. They were seized following his arrest in 1991. (AP)
Estonian police say bankers may have laundered $13 billion through the country’s financial institutions. Europe is considering new rules to crack down . (Bloomberg, Reuters, Xinhua, Reuters, CM)
Prosecutors defended their use of search warrants in the case against Paul Manafort. (NPR)
Three German organizers of the 2006 World Cup were charged with tax evasion; all three deny the charges. (AP)
Anti-money laundering investigators in the British Virgin Islands had questions about the sale of a Maltese firm. (ToM)
The former finance director at Ping An was convicted . (NZH)
Filipino anti-money laundering regulators are focusing on professions outside of traditional finance. (Rappler)
Cyprus is capping its “golden visa” program. (EA)
A U.S. lobbying firm gets cash from the Azerbaijani Laundromat after burnishing the country’s reputation. (OCCRP, OCCRP)
Sanctions:
Russian bank VTB stopped lending to U.S.-blacklisted oligarch Oleg Deripaska. Mr. Deripaska stepped down from the board of United Co. Rusal; the company asked the Kremlin to buy its aluminum. (MT, AFP, Reuters)
American companies are struggling in Russia due to U.S. sanctions. (MT)
The U.K. gave royal assent to its new sanctions legislation ; a journalist group welcomed the move. (release, Guardian, release)
Europe has to protect trade with Iran to save the nuclear deal, the Iranian leader said . Tehran continues to comply with its end of the agreement. Russia President Vladimir Putin said the U.S. exit from the deal creates world instability. There’s no compromise in sight. German small businesses scramble to find ways to stay in Iran. A French auto company said its Iran strategy is unchanged , while oil company Total SA sees little hope in getting a waiver. There’s no way to avoid the sanctions. (Reuters, WP, CG, BBC, AFP, Reuters, Reuters, AP, Brookings, Reuters, Reuters, Reuters, Reuters, Bloomberg)
The latest U.S. sanctions on Iran are targeting Tehran’s activity in Yemen and the aircraft personally used by Iran’s president. (JS, AJE, Bloomberg)
Whistleblowers:
Guam is considering whether to pay tax-fraud whistleblowers. (GDP)
General Anti-Corruption:
The U.S. special counsel’s probe continues amid new reports of meetings between Michael Cohen and Russian oligarchs , and the flipping of Mr. Cohen’s business partner . One witness claims his emails were hacked . A defendant who pleaded guilty is set for sentencing . Rudy Giuliani, U.S. President Donald Trump’s lawyer, has gone back and forth on whether the president should sit down with the prosecutor. Mr. Trump continues his attacks . (TPM, NYT, ABC, CNN, NYT, NYT, ABC, NYDN, Forward, Politico, Politico, ABC, Politico, WP, AP, VF, Politico, Politico, HuffPost, DB)
U.S. prosecutors have launched a criminal probe into bitcoin price manipulation.
Former South Africa president Jacob Zuma is too broke to mount a defense against corruption charges. His ally resigned . The government is using drones to prevent corruption. (News24, BL, Reuters, Quartz)
Ghana police opened a criminal corruption probe into the soccer chief. There was no response from the national association as he surrendered . (AFP, IWF)
Ukraine’s government fooled the West on developing an antigraft court. (KP)
White-collar crime prosecutions dropped to their lowest level in 20 years. (TRAC)
